section.title: Activity Workflow
section.t: The very first step is to find the Activity Streams endpoint. A Consumer wishing to access a user's Activity Stream can start with an Initial Identifier for the Service Provider containing the user's data, usually provided by the user. In most cases, this may be the domain name of the Service Provider's web site, such as bestsite.com. Consumers can then perform Discovery on the Initial Identifier to determine where the Activity Streams endpoint for this Service Provider resides. If successful, the Consumer may then attempt to request information from that endpoint. If the endpoint contains private data, the Service Provider will return an authorization challenge, and the Consumer must then guide the user through an appropriate authorization flow to obtain the credentials necessary to access this private data. Upon successful authorization, the Consumer may request data from the Activity Streams endpoint using these authorization credentials. Whether accessing public or private data, Consumers may request a specific subset of the user's data using standard Query Parameters. Upon a successful request, the data is returned in the response, and the Consumer may then parse the response data and use it as desired.
If the Consumer wishes to maintain an in sync copy of the data or get new activities as soon as they are available POSTed to them via web hooks they should subscribe via the
The following sections detail each of these steps.

section.title: Discovery
section.t: Providers who support this specification SHOULD promote their conformance by making the Activity Stream API endpoint discoverable from the root of the domain using . The API is identified by the Service Type http://activitystrea.ms/api/0.1 In addition, the url for the Activity Streams end point MUST be documented for human consumption by the Service Provider in their API documentation. The documentation MUST include the version of the Activity Streams API supported. The current version is 0.1

section.title: Retrieval of Activities
section.t: All content fetching requests to the Service Provider are made as HTTP GET operations on a URL deriving form the base URL described in section 2.1. section.t: The activities returned from the Activity Stream endpoint MAY contain a mix of public and private data. [TODO: Example]. If Service Providers wish to make some response data publicly available and also provide additional info given the proper authorization credentials, they SHOULD provide a 200 OK response to requests without authorization with a WWW-Authenticate header in the response indicating that additional info is available via the specified authorization mechanisms.

section.title: Synchronization
section.t: In order to keep the data synchronized it is possible to repeatedly invoke the Activity Streams endpoint using GET and passing if-modified-since headers. This concept is known as polling and it is not considered the most efficient for keeping multiple repositories of data in synch. The Activity Streams endpoint SHOULD support subscriptions so consumers can enjoy near real time updates without much expense using

section.title: Types
section.t: The following sections define the different types that represent concepts from the activity streams data model in JSON.

section.title: Activity
section.t: An Activity represents an activity as defined by the Activity Streams specifications.
An Activity has the following properties:

list.t: A URI that serves as an identifier for this activity. If not present then the permalinkUrl will be used in its place. For the full definition see Section 3.1.1 of
The URL of an icon represents this activity. This property MAY be null if there are no specific icons per activity type for this activity publisher
The time that the activity occurred, as a W3CDTF timestamp as defined in Section 3.1.3 of
The actor of this activity as defined in Section 3.1.4 of
The list of verb URIs for this activity as defined in Section 3.1.5 of
The object of this activity as defined in Section 3.1.6
The target of this activity as defined in Section 3.1.7
The URL of a HTML page that represents this activity as defined in Section 3.1.9 of
An HTML representation of the natural language title for this activity as defined in Section 3.1.10 of
An HTML representation of a natural language describing this activity including visual elements such as thumbnails as defined in Section 3.1.11 of
An array of identifiers which describe how the consumer can deliver the updates as defined in Section 3.1.12 of

section.t: If additional properties are present in an Activity, they MUST be ignored.

section.title: Object
section.t: Object is the base type of objects that can be referenced by activities. Specific object types will extend this basic object with additional properties that are specific to the object type in question.

list.t: Unique identifier for the object. If not present in the JSON response, assume it matches the permalinkURL. For more details on the format for the id see Section 3.2.1 on
Label for the object meant for human consumption. For more details on the displayName see Section 3.2.2 on
Description or snippet of the object if this textual. For more details see Section 3.2.3 on
Link to human readable representation of the object. If the id is not present, then this field will be considered the id. For more details see Section 3.2.5 on
Representative image as described in Section 3.2.4 of
An array of URIs which identify the object type. For more details see Section 3.2.6

section.title: ActivityStream
section.t: An activity stream is a collection of activities. Often these activities are related in some way, such as being by the same actor.
An ActivityStream has the following properties:

list.t: A human-readable name for this stream. This property MAY be null if the stream has no name.
The language used to generate the summary and content sections of the activities.
The activities comprising this stream. This property MUST NOT be null.
A URI that serves as an identifier for this activity stream. This property MUST NOT be null.

If this stream is considered to be about a specific object -- usually a Person -- the publisher SHOULD include the object representation for the subject. If included then only the minimal representation is necessary in subsequent references.
